pullRequest.title: Adding ResponseHandler to implement backoff retry strageies based on response code.

commit.message:
Adding ResponseHandler in FIS SDK to implement backoff retry strageies
based on response code.

nodes.bodyText: nit: double negation looks a bit hard to read to me.
What will happen in the case of the request success? Will we still backoff? It seems that the backoff reset is not implemented.
I wonder what's the intended used of  isRequestAllowed method? Will this line lead to the method returning false until setNextAllowedRequestTime() method is called?
I think tests for the reset case will be beneficial. Tests that cover ResponseHandler.java lines 80-83 as well.
If I'm not mistaken, there may be other success codes we receive, e.g. 201 when FIS created. Would it be better to be more generic and treat all codes between 200 and 300 as success?

out of curiosity:
what does @hide mean/do?

I probably asked this before:
Any chance we can inject a timesource here or any instance that can be overwritten in different environments?
Not important at all.
But if we plan to do something about this, then maybe add a comment or TODO.

What's the point of this method?
Maybe a JavaDoc?

Generally not a fan of classes that are called "Utils".
Seems like a dump for all methods that have no home, haha
Maybe we can have a time class that deals with all time related methods and has all time related constants, and call it "TimeSource" or "SystemTime" or "Clock" or something?
And another class that deals with validation and input checking, called "Validator" or something.
Even better would be if all these methods could find a home in the respective model classes (assuming that we have model classes).
Example: #isAuthTokenExpired goes into the AuthToken model class.

It seems to me that this class is not handling responses, but rather response stati.
How about one of the following names:

RequestLimiter  (my favorite so far)
BackoffStrategy
ResponseStatusHandler

nodes.bodyText: #setNextRequestTime?

Usually it's better to not use negations in method (or variable) names.
Options:

isConfigurationProblem (my favorite so far)
isRetryableError and use negations above
How about instead we set attemptCount = 0.

Why do we set this at all?
Can we just ignore this value or set it to -1?
It seems like you are abusing some existing constant (i.e. Long.MAX_VALUE) for semantic purposes.
If that is the case, I recommend to rather introduce your own constant that has a speaking name.
Example: NEXT_REQUEST_TIME_IMMEDIATELY or something similar.
#getBackoffDuration

constants?
don't we have those defined somewhere already?

SOME_RETRYABLE_RESPONSE_CODE
or
RETRYABLE_RESPONSE_CODE_EXAMPLE

I don't think this is a problem, but I want to call it out:
If the end-user changes the system-time to the past, the app will stop working.
This problem will be fixed by restarting the app and usually end-users changing system-clock know this - at least I knew whenever I have done similar things in the past, haha
Maybe add a short comment here to call this out?
Please add a respective comment (not Javadoc) to the code.

a) Please add a respective comment to the code.
b) Just to be sure we are on the same page:
If this class were to use a proper TimeSource, this issue would not exist and tests could mock the TimeSource instance instead.
Please add a respective comment (not JavaDoc) to the method.
Just seeing this. Some comments above may allude to this ...

Let's remove the word "allowed".
The next sentence is explaining that it also checks if a request is allowed.
